summary:
Me: Today I did chemistry all day. I mean real chemistry. 
Somebody else: What? I saw you watching Good Omens all day. 
Me: I...
body:
Me: Today I did chemistry all day. I mean real chemistry.

Somebody else: What? I saw you watching Good Omens all day.

Me: I studied the hell out of it.

Oh, common, just look at them. Isn’t it hot in here?

summary: Ok, after that GoT fiasco, the Good Omens was the best thing that could happen to the world. Really, it has everything I hoped...
body: Ok, after that GoT fiasco, the Good Omens was the best thing that could happen to the world. Really, it has everything I hoped for (except maybe for the additional four riders of the apocalypse). And I really wasn’t prepared for that holy water bath scene.

reblog.comment: Ok, after that GoT fiasco, the Good Omens was the best thing that could happen to the world. Really, it has everything I hoped for (except maybe for the additional four riders of the apocalypse). And I really wasn’t prepared for that holy water bath scene.

summary: Aziraphale’s Flaming Sword  is definitely one of my favorite parts about the show. It starts off as the instrument of...
caption:
Aziraphale’s Flaming Sword is definitely one of my favorite parts about the show.

It starts off as the instrument of Aziraphale, Angel of the Eastern Gate, given to him by God themselves, is subsequently handed down to Adam to help him protect himself and Eve against animals and the Cold. In an ironic twist, the sword becomes the summon and weapon of War. Quite a curious commentary as to how things that we claim possession of in order to protect ourselves oft result in bringing greater violence unto others.

It seems fitting though, to see it being used to vanquish War itself, not through violence, rather a declaration of peace. In its time away from Aziraphale, it’s nature and duty is changed. It is no longer an instrument used to protect the Garden of Eden, rather something else entirely.

The Ineffable Plan really does account for everything.

blog.name: its-ineffable-my-dear
blog.title: Blash Fastard
blog.description: I literally kept seeing Good Omens in Waterstones and now its ruined me

body:
Basically…

Ok so this blog is dedicated to all things Good Omens, even though I suppose the hype may die down now idek??

So I kept seeing this book as I was growing up in the table at Waterstones, might’ve picked it up once when I was 12 and thought it’s too grown up for me (lol look at me being mature not like much has changed right right?)

Ultimately this is a place just to talk about Good Omens, post memes, gifs, reblog shit and write stuff hopefully. Maybe will take requests in the foreseeable future but will be focusing of fan fiction rn x

Wanna talk about Good Omens? Go for it! Wanna rant about how good/bad (😟) the series was? Yah sure!! Or just wanna talk/vent/type the whole of pie to me! Shoot cowboy/girl!!

See ya you ethereal beings 🥰😈😇

tags: these guys have my whole heart
body:
These guys…

I can’t get over Crowley’s face when Aziraphale shows up in the bar and he mentions the bookshop. Crowley looks so sad about having to tell him it burnt down. And before that when he says that he lost his best friend. I lost it at this scene.

summary: sksklkflsafskld Neil Gaiman reblogged my post last night. I was hoping but not at all expecting that he’d see it <3  Good Omens...
body:
sksklkflsafskld Neil Gaiman reblogged my post last night. I was hoping but not at all expecting that he’d see it <3 

Good Omens is everything I wanted and more. We have to keep pausing it to finish laughing without missing what happens next in the show. Michael Sheen as Aziraphale is my favorite part of the whole thing. Aziraphale is so brilliantly portrayed and Michael is so expressive with his face it’s so so good.
